#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-banner-sdk {background-color: #FFF5E5;}

#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-policy-text,
#onetrust-consent-sdk .ot-b-addl-desc,
#onetrust-consent-sdk .ot-dpd-desc,
#onetrust-consent-sdk .ot-dpd-title,

#onetrust-consent-sdk .ot-dpd-desc *:not(.onetrust-vendors-list-handler),

#onetrust-banner-sdk .ot-cat-header {
color: #000000;
}
#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-banner-sdk .banner-option-details {
background-color: #E9E9E9;}
#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-banner-sdk a[href],
#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-banner-sdk a[href] font,
#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-banner-sdk .ot-link-btn
{
color: #000000;
}#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-accept-btn-handler,
#onetrust-banner-sdk #onetrust-reject-all-handler {
background-color: #99261E;border-color: #99261E;
color: #FFFFFF;
}
#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-banner-sdk *:focus,
#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-banner-sdk:focus {
outline-color: #000000;
outline-width: 1px;
}
#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-pc-btn-handler,
#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-pc-btn-handler.cookie-setting-link {
color: #000000; border-color: #000000;
background-color:
#FFF5E5;
} #onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-banner-sdk #onetrust-close-btn-container {
top: 25px;
right: 25px;
}
#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-banner-sdk .onetrust-close-btn-ui {
width: 12px;
height: 12px;
}
#onetrust-banner-sdk #onetrust-policy-text a.ot-sdk-show-settings {
margin-left: 0;
}
#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-button-group {
text-align: center;
}
#onetrust-pc-sdk .ot-tgl .ot-label-status {
display: block!important;
}
@media only screen and (min-width: 425px) and (max-width: 550px) {
#onetrust-banner-sdk.ot-iab-2 #onetrust-button-group-parent #onetrust-button-group {
width: auto;
}
}
@media only screen and (min-width: 426px) and (max-width: 896px) {
#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-banner-sdk .onetrust-close-btn-ui {
top: 0;
right: 0;
}
}
@media (min-width: 896px) {
#onetrust-banner-sdk .ot-sdk-three.ot-sdk-columns {
left: auto;
right: 4%;
margin-left: 0;
margin-top: 5%;
}
}
@media only screen and (min-width: 769px) {
#onetrust-banner-sdk #onetrust-button-group {
margin-right: 0;
}
}
@media only screen and (min-width: 1024px){
#onetrust-banner-sdk.ot-iab-2 #onetrust-button-group-parent {
margin-top: .25em;
}
}
html:has(>body>div#onetrust-consent-sdk.show-banner) {
overflow-y: hidden;
}
html:has(>body>div#onetrust-consent-sdk.show-banner>div.onetrust-pc-dark-filter[style*="none"]) {
overflow-y: auto;
}
/* hides banner after it has already been interacted with */
#onetrust-consent-sdk:not(.show-banner) #onetrust-banner-sdk {
display: none;
}</style>

,"headline": "Shrimp Étouffée"

]
,"description": "This classic Louisiana Shrimp Étouffée can be on the dinner table in just over an hour. All you'll need is some hot sauce and plenty bread, and dinner's ready."

,"name": "Shrimp Étouffée"
,"aggregateRating": {
"@type": "AggregateRating",
"ratingValue": "4.7",
"ratingCount": "9"
}
, "recipeCategory": ["Entree","Dinner"]
,"recipeCuisine": ["American","Southern","Cajun"]
,"recipeIngredient": [
"1/2 cup (4 oz.) salted butter",
"1/3 cup (about 1 1/2 oz.) all-purpose flour",
"2 cups chopped yellow onion (from 1 large onion)",
"1/2 cup chopped celery (from 1 large stalk)",
"2 teaspoons minced garlic (from 1 large garlic clove)",
"1/2 cup chopped red bell pepper (from 1 medium bell pepper)",
"1/2 cup chopped green bell pepper (from 1 medium bell pepper)",
"1 cup chicken broth",
"1 cup water",
"2 pounds medium peeled, deveined raw shrimp",
"2 teaspoons hot sauce",
"1 1/4 teaspoons kosher salt",
"1/2 teaspoon black pepper",
"1/4 cup chopped scallions (from 2 scallions)",
"1/4 cup chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley",
"Hot cooked long-grain white rice" ]
,"recipeInstructions": [
{
"@type": "HowToStep"
,"text": "Melt butter in a large Dutch oven over medium-low; whisk in flour. Cook, whisking constantly, until mixture turns golden brown, 10 to 12 minutes. Increase heat to medium, and add onion, celery, and garlic. Cook, stirring often, until soft and golden, about 15 minutes."
} ,{
"@type": "HowToStep"
,"text": "Stir in bell peppers, and cook, stirring often, 5 minutes. Stir in broth and water, and cook, stirring constantly, until mixture thickens, 7 to 10 minutes. Stir in shrimp, and cook, stirring occasionally, until shrimp turn pink, about 5 minutes. Stir in hot sauce, salt, and pepper; cook 5 more minutes. Stir in scallions and parsley, and simmer 5 minutes. Remove from heat. Cover and let stand 5 minutes. Serve immediately over hot cooked rice."
} ]
,"totalTime": "PT75M"

"reviewBody": "Yes, it does total 15 minutes of cooking time for the shrimp, in 3, 5-minute steps. I put the 5-minute shrimp step as the final cooking step. I also added a teaspoon of Cajun seasoning for a flavor boost.",

<h1 class="article-heading text-headline-400">Shrimp Étouffée</h1>
<div id="mm-recipes-review-bar_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-review-bar mntl-block has-ratings has-comments js-recipe-review-bar"><div id="mm-recipes-review-bar__star-rating_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-review-bar__star-rating mntl-recipe-star-rating mm-recipes-star-rating" data-track-rating-location="Top Nav - Jump to Reviews - Stars">

<div id="mm-recipes-review-bar__rating_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-review-bar__rating mntl-text-block text-label-300 global-link">4.7</div>
<div id="mm-recipes-review-bar__rating-count_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-review-bar__rating-count mntl-text-block text-utility-300">(9)</div>
<div id="mm-recipes-review-bar__comment-count_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-review-bar__comment-count mntl-text-block text-label-300 global-link">6 Reviews</div></div>
<p class="article-subheading text-body-100">This classic Louisiana Shrimp Étouffée can be on the dinner table in just over an hour. All you'll need is some hot sauce and plenty bread, and dinner's ready.</p>
<div id="mntl-article-meta-dynamic_1-0" class="comp mntl-article-meta-dynamic mntl-article-meta mntl-block" data-tracking-container="true"><div id="southernliving-bylines_1-0" class="comp southernliving-bylines mntl-bylines text-utility-200"><div id="mntl-bylines__group_1-0" class="comp mntl-bylines__group mntl-block mntl-bylines__group--author"><div id="mntl-bylines__item_1-0" class="comp mntl-bylines__item mntl-attribution__item mntl-attribution__item--has-date">
<span class="mntl-attribution__item-descriptor">By</span>
<div data-tooltip="<p>Patricia was the assistant food editor at Southern Living and worked with the Southern Living food team from 2006-2022. She contributed to articles about food, gardening, and pets.</p>" tabindex="0" data-inline-tooltip="true"> <a
href="https://www.southernliving.com/author/patricia-s-york"
rel="nocaes"
data-trigger-link="true"
class="mntl-attribution__item-name"
tabindex="-1"
>Patricia S York</a>
<div id="mntl-author-tooltip_1-0" class="comp mntl-author-tooltip mntl-tooltip mntl-group"> <div class="mntl-author-tooltip__top ">
<div class="mntl-author-tooltip__image-wrapper">

<div id="mm-recipes-intro_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-intro mntl-block"><div id="mm-recipes-intro__jump-to-recipe_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-intro__jump-to-recipe southernliving-jump-to-recipe mm-recipes-jump-to-recipe mntl-block"><button id="mm-recipes-jump-to-recipe__button_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-jump-to-recipe__button mntl-button text-label-300 button--contained-standard"> Jump to recipe
<svg class="icon icon-arrow-down mntl-button__icon "
>
<use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#icon-arrow-down" href="#icon-arrow-down"></use>
</svg>
</button></div>
<div id="mm-recipes-intro__content_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-intro__content mntl-sc-page mntl-block " data-sc-sticky-offset="190" data-sc-ad-label-height="24" data-sc-ad-track-spacing="100" data-sc-min-track-height="250" data-sc-max-track-height="600" data-sc-breakpoint="50em" data-sc-load-immediate="1" data-sc-content-positions="[1, 1250, 1550, 1950, 2350, 2750, 3150, 3550, 3950]" data-bind-scroll-on-start="true"><p id="mntl-sc-block_1-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> This classic Louisiana dish can be on the dinner table in just over an hour. Have all of the ingredients prepped and ready to go before you start cooking. To make the meal come together even faster, you can cook the rice ahead of time and reheat it before serving. Once dinner's done, all you'll need is some hot sauce and plenty of crusty bread for mopping up all the rich, velvety sauce. Not a fan of shrimp? Substitute <a href="https://www.southernliving.com/food/whats-for-supper/cajun-recipes" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">crawfish tail meat</a>.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_2-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>

<div id="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-structured-ingredients"><div id="mm-recipes-cook-mode_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-cook-mode" data-screen-wake-locked="false"> <button class="mm-recipes-cook-mode__button" aria-pressed="false" aria-label="Toggle Cook Mode">

Cook Mode

</div><div class="loc heading"><h2 id="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__heading_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__heading mntl-text-block">Ingredients</h2>
</div> <ul class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list">
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true">1/2</span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true">cup</span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">(4 oz.) salted butter</span></p>
</li>
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true">1/3</span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true">cup</span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">(about 1 1/2 oz.) all-purpose flour</span></p>
</li>
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true">2</span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true">cups</span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">chopped yellow onion (from 1 large onion)</span></p>
</li>
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true">1/2</span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true">cup</span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">chopped celery (from 1 large stalk)</span></p>
</li>
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true">2</span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true">teaspoons</span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">minced garlic (from 1 large garlic clove)</span></p>
</li>
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true">1/2</span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true">cup</span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">chopped red bell pepper (from 1 medium bell pepper)</span></p>
</li>
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true">1/2</span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true">cup</span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">chopped green bell pepper (from 1 medium bell pepper)</span></p>
</li>
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true">1</span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true">cup</span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">chicken broth</span></p>
</li>
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true">1</span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true">cup</span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">water</span></p>
</li>
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true">2</span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true">pounds</span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">medium peeled, deveined raw shrimp</span></p>
</li>
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true">2</span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true">teaspoons</span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">hot sauce</span></p>
</li>
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true">1 1/4</span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true">teaspoons</span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">kosher salt</span></p>
</li>
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true">1/2</span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true">teaspoon</span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">black pepper</span></p>
</li>
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true">1/4</span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true">cup</span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">chopped scallions (from 2 scallions)</span></p>
</li>
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true">1/4</span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true">cup</span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley</span></p>
</li>
<li
class="mm-recipes-structured-ingredients__list-item "
>
<p><span data-ingredient-quantity="true"></span> <span data-ingredient-unit="true"></span> <span data-ingredient-name="true">Hot cooked long-grain white rice</span></p>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div id="mm-recipes-steps_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-steps mntl-block"><h2 id="mm-recipes-steps__heading_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-steps__heading mntl-text-block">Directions</h2>
<div id="mm-recipes-steps__content_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-steps__content mntl-sc-page mntl-block "><OL id="mntl-sc-block_4-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-startgroup mntl-sc-block-group--OL">
<LI id="mntl-sc-block_5-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-startgroup mntl-sc-block-group--LI">
<p id="mntl-sc-block_6-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> Melt butter in a large Dutch oven over medium-low; whisk in flour. Cook, whisking constantly, until mixture turns golden brown, 10 to 12 minutes. Increase heat to medium, and add onion, celery, and garlic. Cook, stirring often, until soft and golden, about 15 minutes.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_7-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
</LI>
<LI id="mntl-sc-block_9-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-startgroup mntl-sc-block-group--LI">
<p id="mntl-sc-block_10-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> Stir in bell peppers, and cook, stirring often, 5 minutes. Stir in broth and water, and cook, stirring constantly, until mixture thickens, 7 to 10 minutes. Stir in shrimp, and cook, stirring occasionally, until shrimp turn pink, about 5 minutes. Stir in hot sauce, salt, and pepper; cook 5 more minutes. Stir in scallions and parsley, and simmer 5 minutes. Remove from heat. Cover and let stand 5 minutes. Serve immediately over hot cooked rice.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_11-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
</LI>
</OL></div></div>

<div id="mm-ads-taxAggregator-iframe_1-0" class="comp mm-ads-taxAggregator-iframe"> <div id="taxAggregatorWrapper" style="display: none !important;">
<script>
if (document.getElementById("taxAggregatorIframe") === null) {
const iframe = document.createElement("iframe");
iframe.id = "taxAggregatorIframe";
document.getElementById("taxAggregatorWrapper").appendChild(iframe);
const dotDashOrigin = "https://www.dotdashmeredith.com";
const sendTaxDataToIframe = () => {
const { primaryTaxonomyIds } = {"primaryTaxonomyIds":"5510039|6541470|6541450"};
const tax2 = primaryTaxonomyIds?.split("|")?.[2];
if (tax2 !== undefined) {
iframe.contentWindow.postMessage(
{
tax2
},
dotDashOrigin,
);
}
}
// when iframe loads, send it the taxonomy data
iframe.addEventListener("load", sendTaxDataToIframe);
// The "load" event fires regardless of whether the network request succeeded/failed,
// but we can test for a successful load by sending a message from the iframe itself.
// Message is sent here - https://bitbucket.prod.aws.about.com/projects/REVDEV/repos/private-aggregation-api-frontend/browse/index.html
let iframeLoaded = false;
window.addEventListener("message", event => {
if (event.origin === dotDashOrigin && event.data === "success") {
iframeLoaded = true;
}
});
window.addEventListener("readyForThirdPartyTracking", () => {
iframe.setAttribute("src", dotDashOrigin + "/privateAggregationAPI/index.html");
});
setTimeout(() => {
if (iframeLoaded === false) {
console.error("Private Aggregation API document failed to load from dotdashmeredith.com (mm-ads module)");
}
}, 6000);
}
</script>

Ingredients: ['(4 oz.) salted butter', '(about 1 1/2 oz.) all-purpose flour', 'chopped yellow onion (from 1 large onion)', 'chopped celery (from 1 large stalk)', 'minced garlic (from 1 large garlic clove)', 'chopped red bell pepper (from 1 medium bell pepper)', 'chopped green bell pepper (from 1 medium bell pepper)', 'chicken broth', 'water', 'medium peeled, deveined raw shrimp', 'hot sauce', 'kosher salt', 'black pepper', 'chopped scallions (from 2 scallions)', 'chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley', 'Hot cooked long-grain white rice']
Methods: ['Melt butter in a large Dutch oven over medium-low; whisk in flour.', 'Cook, whisking constantly, until mixture turns golden brown, 10 to 12 minutes.', 'Increase heat to medium, and add onion, celery, and garlic.', 'Cook, stirring often, until soft and golden, about 15 minutes.', 'Stir in bell peppers, and cook, stirring often, 5 minutes.', 'Stir in broth and water, and cook, stirring constantly, until mixture thickens, 7 to 10 minutes.', 'Stir in shrimp, and cook, stirring occasionally, until shrimp turn pink, about 5 minutes.', 'Stir in hot sauce, salt, and pepper; cook 5 more minutes.', 'Stir in scallions and parsley, and simmer 5 minutes.', 'Remove from heat.', 'Cover and let stand 5 minutes.', 'Serve immediately over hot cooked rice.', '']

},

, "recipeCategory": ["Entree","Dinner","Soup"]
,"recipeCuisine": ["Southern","Cajun","Creole"]
,"recipeIngredient": [
"1 pound andouille sausage, cut into 1/4-inch-thick slices",
"4 skinned bone-in chicken breasts",
"Vegetable oil",
".75 cup all-purpose flour",
"1 medium onion, chopped",
".5 green bell pepper, chopped",
"2 celery ribs, sliced",
"2 quarts hot water",
"3 garlic cloves, minced",
"2 bay leaves",
"1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce",
"2 teaspoons Creole seasoning",
".5 teaspoon dried thyme",
".5 - 1 teaspoon hot sauce",
"4 green onions, sliced",
"Filé powder (optional)",
"Hot cooked rice",
"Garnish: chopped green onions" ]
,"recipeInstructions": [
{
"@type": "HowToStep"
,"image": [
{
"@type": "ImageObject",
"url": "https://www.southernliving.com/thmb/K_FM7A7AQyu0GDD4pa_jtHEKoU0=/1500x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc()/Southern-Living-chicken-and-sausage-gumbo-step-1--1863-8070b8ad7237421ab97ef3d8797c05a2.jpg"
}
]
,"text": "Cook sausage: Cook sausage in a Dutch oven over medium heat, stirring constantly, 5 minutes or until browned. Drain on paper towels, reserving drippings in Dutch oven. Set sausage aside."
} ,{
"@type": "HowToStep"
,"image": [
{
"@type": "ImageObject",
"url": "https://www.southernliving.com/thmb/8osOR8RmpxXZmX0F5RP79i1jRQg=/1500x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc()/Southern-Living-chicken-and-sausage-gumbo-step-2-1865-9259ad79957147438b3a3fbcfbdc5b58.jpg"
}
]
,"text": "Cook chicken: Cook chicken in reserved drippings in Dutch oven over medium heat 5 minutes or until browned. Remove to paper towels, reserving drippings in Dutch oven. Set chicken aside."
} ,{
"@type": "HowToStep"
,"image": [
{
"@type": "ImageObject",
"url": "https://www.southernliving.com/thmb/4IXJeBWQvDXziUMMbOYWbYvHmz8=/1500x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc()/Southern-Living-chicken-and-sausage-gumbo-step-3-1882-adfc06fc4dd343eb99b4e1b95ab323ce.jpg"
}
]
,"text": "Make the roux: Add enough oil to drippings in Dutch oven to measure 1/2 cup. Add flour, and cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, 20 to 25 minutes, or until roux is chocolate colored."
} ,{
"@type": "HowToStep"
,"text": "Simmer the gumbo: Stir in onion, bell pepper, and celery; cook, stirring often, 8 minutes or until tender. Gradually add 2 quarts hot water, and bring mixture to a boil; add chicken, garlic, and next 5 ingredients. Reduce heat to low, and simmer, stirring occasionally, 1 hour. Remove chicken; let cool."
} ,{
"@type": "HowToStep"
,"text": "Add sausage: Add sausage to gumbo; cook 30 minutes. Stir in green onions; cook for 30 more minutes."
} ,{
"@type": "HowToStep"
,"image": [
{
"@type": "ImageObject",
"url": "https://www.southernliving.com/thmb/le6xenmpFnaM-fDVKnKfIOiO0jE=/1500x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc()/Southern-Living-chicken-and-sausage-gumbo-step-4-1889-8410102982474d28b6b596644827b549.jpg"
}
]
,"text": "Finish the gumbo: Bone chicken, and cut meat into strips; return chicken to gumbo, and simmer 5 minutes. Remove and discard bay leaves."
} ,{
"@type": "HowToStep"
,"text": "Prepare to serve: Remove gumbo from heat. Sprinkle with filé powder, if desired. Serve over hot cooked rice. Garnish, if desired."
} ]

{
"@type": "Review",
"reviewRating": {
"@type": "Rating",
"ratingValue": "5"
},
"author": {
"@type": "Person",
"name": "Joyce Feltz"
},
"reviewBody": "It amazes me when people write a review and claim it is bland or needs this or that. Recipes like these require tweaking to ones taste. This is a great basic recipe for gumbo! If you taste along the way, you may realize you need to add this or that to suit your tastes. I guess I'm more of an intuitive cook, and don't expect a basic recipe to meet all of my flavor expectations. Maybe that takes time and experience. I hate baking, because everything needs to be measured and recipes followed exactly. Not my style.",
"datePublished": "2024-06-29T01:06:25.256Z"
}
,
{
"@type": "Review",
"reviewRating": {

},
"author": {
"@type": "Person",
"name": "Southern Living Member"
},
"reviewBody": "It was simple to follow and prepare. I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil and I added cod fish.",

,

"reviewBody": "Great recipe. Worked very well and developed great flavor. A keeper of a recipe. If your recipe was bland - maybe check sausage brand and seasoning brand.",

, "about": [
{
"@type": "FAQPage",
"mainEntity": [
{
"@type": "Question",
"name": "What is the secret to good gumbo?",
"acceptedAnswer": {
"@type": "Answer",
"text": "<p>The secret to a great gumbo is the <a href=\"https://www.southernliving.com/how-to-make-a-roux-7092953\" data-component=\"link\" data-source=\"inlineLink\" data-type=\"internalLink\" data-ordinal=\"1\">roux<\/a>—a thickener made by cooking flour and fat until browned to a light or dark color, depending on the recipe at hand. The dark brown roux used in this gumbo helps build deep flavor in the dish.<\/p>"
}
}
,
{
"@type": "Question",
"name": "Should gumbo be thick or soupy?",
"acceptedAnswer": {
"@type": "Answer",
"text": "<p>The consistency of gumbo can vary based on who's making it. While it should be thicker than soup, thickeners like roux, okra, and filé powder can be added to thicken to the consistency you prefer.<\/p>"
}
}
,
{
"@type": "Question",
"name": "Is gumbo roux better with butter or oil?",
"acceptedAnswer": {
"@type": "Answer",
"text": "<p>While some cooks choose a combination of both oil and butter when making a roux, each imparts its own flavor and benefits. Oil has a high smoke point, and can be used for prolonged cooking without burning, while butter adds a rich, buttery flavor and mouthfeel.<\/p>"
}
}
,
{
"@type": "Question",
"name": "Why do you put vinegar in gumbo?",
"acceptedAnswer": {
"@type": "Answer",
"text": "<p>Adding vinegar to gumbo helps balance the richness of the dish by cutting through the meat, roux, and spices to help brighten the dish.<\/p>"
}
}
]
} ] }

</div> <div class="mntl-author-tooltip__bio">
<p>The Southern Living Test Kitchen has been publishing recipes since 1970, four years after the first issue of Southern Living Magazine appeared on newsstands. The Southern Living Test Kitchen team includes a team of professionals with deep expertise in recipe development, from pastry chefs and grilling experts to nutritionists and dietitians. Together, the team tests and retests, produces, styles, and photographs thousands of recipes each year in the state-of-the-art test kitchen facility located in Birmingham, Alabama.</p>
</div>

<div id="mm-recipes-intro_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-intro mntl-block"><div id="mm-recipes-intro__jump-to-recipe_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-intro__jump-to-recipe southernliving-jump-to-recipe mm-recipes-jump-to-recipe mntl-block"><button id="mm-recipes-jump-to-recipe__button_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-jump-to-recipe__button mntl-button text-label-300 button--contained-standard"> Jump to recipe
<svg class="icon icon-arrow-down mntl-button__icon "
>
<use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#icon-arrow-down" href="#icon-arrow-down"></use>
</svg>
</button></div>
<div id="mm-recipes-intro__content_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-intro__content mntl-sc-page mntl-block " data-sc-sticky-offset="190" data-sc-ad-label-height="24" data-sc-ad-track-spacing="100" data-sc-min-track-height="250" data-sc-max-track-height="600" data-sc-breakpoint="50em" data-sc-load-immediate="1" data-sc-content-positions="[1, 1250, 1550, 1950, 2350, 2750, 3150, 3550, 3950]" data-bind-scroll-on-start="true"><p id="mntl-sc-block_1-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> This iconic chicken and sausage gumbo recipe represents everything we love about <a href="https://www.southernliving.com/food/whats-for-supper/cajun-recipes" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">Louisiana cooking</a>. With ordinary ingredients, the right seasonings, and patience, the results are extraordinary.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_2-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_3-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> The secrets to a good <a href="https://www.southernliving.com/food/kitchen-assistant/gumbo-recipes-mardi-gras-new-orleans" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">gumbo</a> aren't anything fancy either, but if you take the time to do them right, your gumbo will be just as good as the ones served in New Orleans.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_4-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_5-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> The first? Make sure to brown the sausage and chicken until they both have crispy caramelization. Secondly, don't fear the <a href="https://www.southernliving.com/how-to-make-a-roux-7092953" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">roux</a>. Brown is the color of flavor so make sure to stir your vegetable oil and flour mixture until it's reached a true chocolate hue. 
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_6-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<figure id="mntl-sc-block_7-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-image mntl-sc-block-universal-image mntl-sc-block-image--no-theme no-theme mntl-sc-block-image figure-landscape figure-high-res"> <div class="figure-media">
<div class="img-placeholder" style="padding-bottom:66.6%;">

</figcaption></figure>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_8-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-featuredlink mntl-sc-block-universal-featured-link mntl-sc-block-universal-featured-link--related"><a
href="https://www.southernliving.com/food/whats-for-supper/cajun-recipes"
rel="nocaes"
id="mntl-sc-block-universal-featured-link__link_1-0"
class="mntl-sc-block-universal-featured-link__link mntl-text-link text-utility-300 global-link"
data-tracking-container="true"
data-tracking-id="featured-link"
><span class="link__wrapper">35 Cajun And Creole Recipes For Dinner, Dessert, And More</span></a>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_9-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<span class="heading-toc" id="toc-what-is-gumbo"></span><h2 id="mntl-sc-block_10-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <span class="mntl-sc-block-heading__text"> What Is Gumbo? </span> </h2>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_11-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> Gumbo originated in the early 18th century in Louisiana, and is a flavorful stew made up of stock, a <a href="https://www.southernliving.com/cajun-holy-trinity-7099631" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">holy trinity</a> of onion, bell pepper, and celery; meat or shellfish, and a thickener—typically a roux, okra, or <a href="https://www.southernliving.com/what-is-file-powder-8584079" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="2">filé powder</a>. A vibrant combination of flavors and textures, this hearty dish is often used as a metaphor for the melting pot of cultures within the state.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_12-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_13-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> You may come across a few unique types of gumbo. <a href="https://www.southernliving.com/recipes/shrimp-okra-gumbo-recipe" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">Creole gumbo</a>, thickened with a light roux and featuring tomatoes, differs from Cajun gumbo, which is thickened with a dark roux, and does not traditionally have tomatoes in the mix. <a href="https://www.southernliving.com/recipes/leah-chase-gumbo-z-herbes" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="2">Gumbo z'herbes</a> is another type of gumbo, made vegetarian to be enjoyed during Lent or for other meatless occasions.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_14-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<span class="heading-toc" id="toc-gumbo-vs-jambalaya"></span><h2 id="mntl-sc-block_15-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <span class="mntl-sc-block-heading__text"> Gumbo vs. Jambalaya </span> </h2>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_16-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> Gumbo and jambalaya are both staples of Cajun and Creole cuisine, with unique flavor profiles based on who's making the dish. The major difference between the two is how they're served—gumbo is served spooned over rice, while <a href="https://www.southernliving.com/recipes/chicken-and-sausage-jambalaya-recipe" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">jambalaya</a> is cooked with rice as a part of the dish.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_17-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_18-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-featuredlink mntl-sc-block-universal-featured-link mntl-sc-block-universal-featured-link--related"><a
href="https://www.southernliving.com/food/seafood/gumbo-vs-jambalaya"
rel="nocaes"
id="mntl-sc-block-universal-featured-link__link_2-0"
class="mntl-sc-block-universal-featured-link__link mntl-text-link text-utility-300 global-link"
data-tracking-container="true"
data-tracking-id="featured-link"
><span class="link__wrapper">What's The Difference Between Gumbo And Jambalaya?</span></a>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_19-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<span class="heading-toc" id="toc-ingredients-for-chicken-and-sausage-gumbo"></span><h2 id="mntl-sc-block_20-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <span class="mntl-sc-block-heading__text"> Ingredients for Chicken and Sausage Gumbo </span> </h2>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_21-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> Andouille sausage, a holy trinity, Creole seasoning, and bone-in chicken breasts combine for this richly flavored chicken and sausage gumbo your family will ask for on repeat. To make chicken and sausage gumbo, you'll need:
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_22-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<ul id="mntl-sc-block_23-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html">
<li><strong>Andouille sausage: </strong>Adds a smoky, spicy richness to the dish.</li>
<li><strong>Bone-in chicken breasts:</strong> The main protein of the gumbo.</li>
<li><strong>Vegetable oil and all-purpose flour: </strong>To create a roux to thicken the gumbo.</li>
<li><strong>Onion, green bell pepper, and celery ribs:</strong> A classic "<a href="https://www.southernliving.com/cajun-holy-trinity-7099631" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">holy trinity</a>" in Cajun and Creole cooking, providing an aromatic base.</li>
<li><strong>Hot water: </strong>To create the broth of the gumbo, although you can also use broth or part stock for deeper flavor.</li>
<li><strong>Garlic cloves: </strong>Adds a savory, aromatic depth.</li>
<li><strong>Bay leaves:</strong> For a subtle herbal flavor.</li>
<li><strong>Worcestershire sauce: </strong>Adds a savory, umami-rich flavor.</li>
<li><strong>Creole seasoning:</strong> A blend of spices including paprika, cayenne, oregano, and thyme, among others for a flavorful result.</li>
<li><strong>Dried thyme: </strong>Adds an earthy, floral quality to the gumbo.</li>
<li><strong>Hot sauce:</strong> For a touch of heat, although you can increase or decrease as you see fit.</li>
<li><strong>Green onions: </strong>Used as a garnish for a fresh, oniony flavor and pop of color.</li>
<li><strong>Filé powder (optional):</strong> Made from ground sassafras leaves to thicken the gumbo and add a unique flavor profile.</li>
<li><strong>Hot cooked rice:</strong> For serving the gumbo.</li>
<li><strong>Green onions: </strong>To garnish the dish.<br></li>
</ul>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_24-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<span class="heading-toc" id="toc-what-is-fil-powder"></span><h2 id="mntl-sc-block_25-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <span class="mntl-sc-block-heading__text"> What Is Filé Powder? </span> </h2>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_26-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> While optional, filé powder is used to flavor and thicken gumbo, and is often used in Louisiana Creole cuisine. It's a seasoning made from dried and ground leaves of North American sassafras trees, with a slightly herbal flavor. It's typically sprinkled over gumbo after cooking to tighten it up and add an earthy flavor, as cooking it too long could cause a stringy result.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_27-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<span class="heading-toc" id="toc-how-to-make-chicken-and-sausage-gumbo"></span><h2 id="mntl-sc-block_28-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <span class="mntl-sc-block-heading__text"> How To Make Chicken and Sausage Gumbo </span> </h2>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_29-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> The best dishes are worth waiting for, and the slow simmer of this gumbo builds deep flavor for a rich and savory blend of ingredients. Full instructions are below, but here's a brief recap before you get started:
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_30-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<ul id="mntl-sc-block_31-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> <li><strong>Step 1. Cook sausage: </strong>Cook sausage in a Dutch oven until browned. Drain on paper towels, reserving drippings. Andouille sausage is technically already cooked, because it's smoked, so you're just getting it nicely crisped and browned.</li><li><strong>Step 2. Cook chicken: </strong>Cook chicken in reserved drippings until browned. Transfer to paper towels, reserving drippings.</li><li><strong>Step 3. Make the roux: </strong>Add enough oil to drippings in Dutch oven to measure 1/2 cup. Add flour, and cook, stirring, until roux is chocolate-colored.</li><li><strong>Step 4. Simmer the gumbo: </strong>Stir in onion, bell pepper, and celery and cook until tender. Gradually add 2 quarts hot water, and bring to a boil. Add chicken, garlic, and next 5 ingredients, reduce heat, and simmer 1 hour. Remove chicken.</li><li><strong>Step 5. Add sausage: </strong>Add sausage and cook 30 minutes. Stir in green onions and cook another 30 minutes.</li><li><strong>Step 6. Finish the gumbo: </strong>Remove chicken bones and cut meat into strips. Return to gumbo and simmer to heat through. Remove bay leaves.</li><li><strong>Step 7. Prepare to serve:</strong> Remove from heat. Sprinkle with filé powder, if desired. Serve over rice and garnish as desired.<br/></li>
</ul>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_32-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_33-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-featuredlink mntl-sc-block-universal-featured-link mntl-sc-block-universal-featured-link--related"><a
href="https://www.southernliving.com/food/dish/gumbo/gumbo-recipe-screw-up"
rel="nocaes"
id="mntl-sc-block-universal-featured-link__link_3-0"
class="mntl-sc-block-universal-featured-link__link mntl-text-link text-utility-300 global-link"
data-tracking-container="true"
data-tracking-id="featured-link"
><span class="link__wrapper">6 Gumbo Cooking Mistakes And How To Avoid Them</span></a>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_34-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<span class="heading-toc" id="toc-can-i-make-chicken-and-sausage-gumbo-ahead"></span><h2 id="mntl-sc-block_35-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <span class="mntl-sc-block-heading__text"> Can I Make Chicken and Sausage Gumbo Ahead? </span> </h2>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_36-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> Gumbo is a great make-ahead dish. To make this dish in advance, cook as directed, then cool completely before transferring to an airtight container. Refrigerate for up to two days for the freshest flavor and reheat on the stovetop before serving.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_37-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<span class="heading-toc" id="toc-how-to-store-and-reheat-leftover-gumbo"></span><h2 id="mntl-sc-block_38-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <span class="mntl-sc-block-heading__text"> How To Store and Reheat Leftover Gumbo </span> </h2>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_39-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> Leftover chicken and sausage gumbo will keep in the refrigerator for up to four days. Store in an airtight container, and reheat on the stovetop until heated throughout. You can also reheat small portions in the microwave as needed.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_40-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_41-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> You can also freeze leftover gumbo in a freezer-safe container or zip-top bag for up to three months. Thaw overnight in the refrigerator, and reheat on the stovetop or in the microwave when ready to serve.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_42-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<span class="heading-toc" id="toc-why-this-recipe-gets-rave-reviews"></span><h2 id="mntl-sc-block_43-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <span class="mntl-sc-block-heading__text"> Why This Recipe Gets Rave Reviews </span> </h2>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_44-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> We love when a recipe gets steller reviews—especially when they come from those who have made it for a number of years with success.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_45-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_46-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> One <em>Southern Living</em> community member commented, "I have made this recipe for years and it is the best gumbo I have ever had, hands down!"
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_47-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_48-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> While another said, "I've made this recipe for the last 10+ years. Being a cajun myself (south of I10 😉 ) this is definitely close to home and also quick and easy for beginners. Definitely my go-to favorite. Let's also mention my family devours it and nothing is left over!! It's requested for holidays and get togethers all the time. Bon Appétit!"
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_49-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>

<div id="mm-recipes-steps_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-steps mntl-block"><h2 id="mm-recipes-steps__heading_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-steps__heading mntl-text-block">Directions</h2>
<div id="mm-recipes-steps__content_1-0" class="comp mm-recipes-steps__content mntl-sc-page mntl-block "><OL id="mntl-sc-block_56-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-startgroup mntl-sc-block-group--OL">
<LI id="mntl-sc-block_57-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-startgroup mntl-sc-block-group--LI">
<h3 id="mntl-sc-block_58-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-subheading mntl-sc-block-subheading"> <span class="mntl-sc-block-subheading__text"> Cook sausage: </span> </h3>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_59-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> Cook sausage in a Dutch oven over medium heat, stirring constantly, 5 minutes or until browned. Drain on paper towels, reserving drippings in Dutch oven. Set sausage aside.
</p>

<h3 id="mntl-sc-block_64-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-subheading mntl-sc-block-subheading"> <span class="mntl-sc-block-subheading__text"> Cook chicken: </span> </h3>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_65-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> Cook chicken in reserved drippings in Dutch oven over medium heat 5 minutes or until browned. Remove to paper towels, reserving drippings in Dutch oven. Set chicken aside.
</p>
<figure id="mntl-sc-block_66-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-image mntl-sc-block-universal-image mntl-sc-block-image--no-theme no-theme mntl-sc-block-image figure-landscape figure-high-res"> <div class="figure-media">

<div id="mntl-sc-block_67-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
</LI>
<LI id="mntl-sc-block_69-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-startgroup mntl-sc-block-group--LI">
<h3 id="mntl-sc-block_70-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-subheading mntl-sc-block-subheading"> <span class="mntl-sc-block-subheading__text"> Make the roux: </span> </h3>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_71-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> Add enough oil to drippings in Dutch oven to measure 1/2 cup. Add flour, and cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, 20 to 25 minutes, or until roux is chocolate colored.
</p>

<div id="mntl-sc-block_73-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
</LI>
<LI id="mntl-sc-block_75-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-startgroup mntl-sc-block-group--LI">
<h3 id="mntl-sc-block_76-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-subheading mntl-sc-block-subheading"> <span class="mntl-sc-block-subheading__text"> Simmer the gumbo: </span> </h3>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_77-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> Stir in onion, bell pepper, and celery; cook, stirring often, 8 minutes or until tender. Gradually add 2 quarts hot water, and bring mixture to a boil; add chicken, garlic, and next 5 ingredients. Reduce heat to low, and simmer, stirring occasionally, 1 hour. Remove chicken; let cool.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_78-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
</LI>
<LI id="mntl-sc-block_80-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-startgroup mntl-sc-block-group--LI">
<h3 id="mntl-sc-block_81-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-subheading mntl-sc-block-subheading"> <span class="mntl-sc-block-subheading__text"> Add sausage: </span> </h3>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_82-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> Add sausage to gumbo; cook 30 minutes. Stir in green onions; cook for 30 more minutes.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_83-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
</LI>
<LI id="mntl-sc-block_85-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-startgroup mntl-sc-block-group--LI">
<h3 id="mntl-sc-block_86-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-subheading mntl-sc-block-subheading"> <span class="mntl-sc-block-subheading__text"> Finish the gumbo: </span> </h3>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_87-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> Bone chicken, and cut meat into strips; return chicken to gumbo, and simmer 5 minutes. Remove and discard bay leaves.
</p>
<figure id="mntl-sc-block_88-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-image mntl-sc-block-universal-image mntl-sc-block-image--no-theme no-theme mntl-sc-block-image figure-landscape figure-high-res"> <div class="figure-media">

<figcaption id="mntl-figure-caption_5-0" class="comp mntl-figure-caption text-utility-100 figure-article-caption"> <span class="figure-article-caption-owner"><p>Dotdash Meredith</p></span>
</figcaption></figure>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_89-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
</LI>
<LI id="mntl-sc-block_91-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-startgroup mntl-sc-block-group--LI">
<h3 id="mntl-sc-block_92-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-subheading mntl-sc-block-subheading"> <span class="mntl-sc-block-subheading__text"> Prepare to serve: </span> </h3>
<p id="mntl-sc-block_93-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-html"> Remove gumbo from heat. Sprinkle with filé powder, if desired. Serve over hot cooked rice. Garnish, if desired.
</p>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_94-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
</LI>
</OL>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_97-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block southernliving-sc-block-faq mntl-sc-block-universal-faq theme-expanded"><span class="heading-toc" id="toc-frequently-asked-questions-8e06b221-89a8-448b-beb0-4900eb0b841e"></span>
<h2 class="mntl-sc-block-universal-faq__title">Frequently Asked Questions</h2>
<ul id="mntl-sc-block-universal-faq__content_1-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block-universal-faq__content mntl-accordion ">
<li class="accordion__item js-accordion-item is-active" data-ordinal="1">
<div tabindex="-1" class="accordion__header js-accordion-trigger" id="mntl-accordion__item_1-0-section-0">
<span class="accordion__title">What is the secret to good gumbo?</span>
</div><!--end accordion__header-->
<div class="accordion__body">
<div id="mntl-accordion__content_1-0" class="comp mntl-accordion__content"> <div class="faq-accordion__item-answer">
<p>The secret to a great gumbo is the <a href="https://www.southernliving.com/how-to-make-a-roux-7092953" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">roux</a>—a thickener made by cooking flour and fat until browned to a light or dark color, depending on the recipe at hand. The dark brown roux used in this gumbo helps build deep flavor in the dish.</p>
</div>
</div> </div><!--end accordion__body-->
</li><!--end accordion__item-->
<li class="accordion__item js-accordion-item is-active" data-ordinal="2">
<div tabindex="-1" class="accordion__header js-accordion-trigger" id="mntl-accordion__item_2-0-section-1">
<span class="accordion__title">Should gumbo be thick or soupy?</span>
</div><!--end accordion__header-->
<div class="accordion__body">
<div id="mntl-accordion__content_2-0" class="comp mntl-accordion__content"> <div class="faq-accordion__item-answer">
<p>The consistency of gumbo can vary based on who's making it. While it should be thicker than soup, thickeners like roux, okra, and filé powder can be added to thicken to the consistency you prefer.</p>
</div>
</div> </div><!--end accordion__body-->
</li><!--end accordion__item-->
<li class="accordion__item js-accordion-item is-active" data-ordinal="3">
<div tabindex="-1" class="accordion__header js-accordion-trigger" id="mntl-accordion__item_3-0-section-2">
<span class="accordion__title">Is gumbo roux better with butter or oil?</span>
</div><!--end accordion__header-->
<div class="accordion__body">
<div id="mntl-accordion__content_3-0" class="comp mntl-accordion__content"> <div class="faq-accordion__item-answer">
<p>While some cooks choose a combination of both oil and butter when making a roux, each imparts its own flavor and benefits. Oil has a high smoke point, and can be used for prolonged cooking without burning, while butter adds a rich, buttery flavor and mouthfeel.</p>
</div>
</div> </div><!--end accordion__body-->
</li><!--end accordion__item-->
<li class="accordion__item js-accordion-item is-active" data-ordinal="4">
<div tabindex="-1" class="accordion__header js-accordion-trigger" id="mntl-accordion__item_4-0-section-3">
<span class="accordion__title">Why do you put vinegar in gumbo?</span>
</div><!--end accordion__header-->
<div class="accordion__body">
<div id="mntl-accordion__content_4-0" class="comp mntl-accordion__content"> <div class="faq-accordion__item-answer">
<p>Adding vinegar to gumbo helps balance the richness of the dish by cutting through the meat, roux, and spices to help brighten the dish.</p>
</div>
</div> </div><!--end accordion__body-->
</li><!--end accordion__item-->
</ul><!--end accordion --></div></div></div>

<div id="mm-ads-taxAggregator-iframe_1-0" class="comp mm-ads-taxAggregator-iframe"> <div id="taxAggregatorWrapper" style="display: none !important;">
<script>
if (document.getElementById("taxAggregatorIframe") === null) {
const iframe = document.createElement("iframe");
iframe.id = "taxAggregatorIframe";
document.getElementById("taxAggregatorWrapper").appendChild(iframe);
const dotDashOrigin = "https://www.dotdashmeredith.com";
const sendTaxDataToIframe = () => {
const { primaryTaxonomyIds } = {"primaryTaxonomyIds":"5510039|6541470|6511168|6511279"};
const tax2 = primaryTaxonomyIds?.split("|")?.[2];
if (tax2 !== undefined) {
iframe.contentWindow.postMessage(
{
tax2
},
dotDashOrigin,
);
}
}
// when iframe loads, send it the taxonomy data
iframe.addEventListener("load", sendTaxDataToIframe);
// The "load" event fires regardless of whether the network request succeeded/failed,
// but we can test for a successful load by sending a message from the iframe itself.
// Message is sent here - https://bitbucket.prod.aws.about.com/projects/REVDEV/repos/private-aggregation-api-frontend/browse/index.html
let iframeLoaded = false;
window.addEventListener("message", event => {
if (event.origin === dotDashOrigin && event.data === "success") {
iframeLoaded = true;
}
});
window.addEventListener("readyForThirdPartyTracking", () => {
iframe.setAttribute("src", dotDashOrigin + "/privateAggregationAPI/index.html");
});
setTimeout(() => {
if (iframeLoaded === false) {
console.error("Private Aggregation API document failed to load from dotdashmeredith.com (mm-ads module)");
}
}, 6000);
}
</script>

Ingredients: ['andouille sausage, cut into 1/4-in.-thick slices', 'skinned bone-in chicken breasts', 'Vegetable oil', 'all-purpose flour', 'medium onion, chopped', 'green bell pepper, chopped', 'celery ribs, sliced', 'hot water', 'garlic cloves, minced', 'bay leaves', 'Worcestershire sauce', 'Creole seasoning', 'dried thyme', 'hot sauce', 'green onions, sliced', 'Filé powder (optional)', 'Hot cooked rice', 'Garnish: chopped green onions']
Methods: ['Cook sausage in a Dutch oven over medium heat, stirring constantly, 5 minutes or until browned.', 'Drain on paper towels, reserving drippings in Dutch oven.', 'Set sausage aside.', 'Cook chicken in reserved drippings in Dutch oven over medium heat 5 minutes or until browned.', 'Remove to paper towels, reserving drippings in Dutch oven.', 'Set chicken aside.', 'Add enough oil to drippings in Dutch oven to measure 1/2 cup.', 'Add flour, and cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, 20 to 25 minutes, or until roux is chocolate colored.', 'Stir in onion, bell pepper, and celery; cook, stirring often, 8 minutes or until tender.', 'Gradually add 2 quarts hot water, and bring mixture to a boil; add chicken, garlic, and next 5 ingredients.', 'Reduce heat to low, and simmer, stirring occasionally, 1 hour.', 'Remove chicken; let cool.', 'Add sausage to gumbo; cook 30 minutes.', 'Stir in green onions; cook for 30 more minutes.', 'Bone chicken, and cut meat into strips; return chicken to gumbo, and simmer 5 minutes.', 'Remove and discard bay leaves.', 'Remove gumbo from heat.', 'Sprinkle with filé powder, if desired.', 'Serve over hot cooked rice.', 'Garnish, if desired.', '']
